title: 3D printing biomaterials for regenerative medicine

author: Rok Kocen, Department for Nanostructured Materials, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: Thank you for the introduction.
So this is Carl, he's diabetic and over the course of years this led to a serious damage to his kidneys, so now he has to take dialysis three times a week, each time for at least three to four hours.
So what's the solution?
Well, he can get a new kidney, but the fact is that a patient like that can wait for a new kidney for at least for around five years.
And the number of people needing organ transplant is increasing and the number of donated organs is pretty much constant, so this is a problem.
And every 30 seconds a patient dies from diseases that could be treated with a tissue replacement.
So is there a way to avoid the need for a donor?
Well, Regina.
Active medicine might have the solution, so the idea is to grow your an organ from your own cells.
Cultivate them in the lab and then place them into a scaffold which is which has the shape of an organ, and then either implanted in vivo.
Or in vitro and grow an organ.
But in all these cases these scaffolds are made from the seller, a disabled pearlized organs.
So we needed an organ before that.
But can we build the scaffold by ourselves?
While 3D bioprinting might be the solution, So what we're working on?
As we've taken conventional 3D printer, modified it to work with bio polymers that we use and then we try to lay them down in layers to form this scaffold.
So this material at the end is hydrogel which is 90% of water, so it resembles our extracellular matrix and my work is to figure out how this material flows in here.
So what?
We have is a hot solution of the material of the biopolymer and then.
We extruded.
Extruded through the nozzle and as it goes the material cools.
On and with that we record the properties of this material, the flow properties, which are called rheological properties and.
From this we can learn how this material flows and how it behaves at which temperatures should be extruded, printed and what are its capabilities.
So for now.
So we are able to print simple geometry's but with improvements of the technique and hardware we are aiming to develop to print more complex shapes and at the end hopefully a new kidney for our Carl.
Thank you very much.
